Despite becoming a father at a very young age, Eliel knew he had to improve his life from the moment he saw his daughter because his family was relying on him. That's why for the last 3 years, with the help of his wife, he has planted potatoes, peas, gladiola flower and beans on land given to him by his father and also on leased land, to increase production. The couple is aware that they owe their livelihood to farming because it allows them to furnish their home and maintain an adequate quality of life. Although his daily work requires self-sacrifice, Eliel is happy because he will soon set up a store in town that his wife will attend to while also being able to care for their daughter, who starts school this year. But Eliel also wishes to complete the expansion of his potato processing factory in Lima city, that he has had to leave aside. He will also continue to increase the scale of his farming. This is his second loan from MFP and he is certain that he will repay it on time. He enjoys working with the members of his community bank because they are good people that are always quick to support one another. Eliel plans to invest the money he is requesting in the purchase of a bag of seeds for planting peas, organic and chemical fertilizers to speed up crop growth, and insecticide for pest control. The photo shows the land that Eliel will be farming.

Translated from Spanish by Vivian Lu, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seed and fertilizer.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en: Lorna is 41 years old, married and has three children. She makes a living selling drinks to both wholesale and retail customers in her community in Lagos. She sells her goods from a stall, and has applied for a loan for NGN 100,000 to buy more crates of drinks to sell. In the future, her goal is to be a major distributor of beverages. Her children are doing well in school and she is determined to give them a high-quality education. Her husband is a pastor, and also helps support their family and their home. Lorna extends her sincerest thanks to all Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more drinks to sell

loans.name: Ruth's Group

texts.en:
Ruth P. is from the village of Bacnor West. She is 50 years old. Ruth is the group leader of a four-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. The official name of this borrowing group is Ruth P.'s group.

Ruth is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Ruth owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. Ruth has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately $65 a month from these activities.

In 2007, Ruth joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Ruth has successfully repaid a previous loan of 10,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Ruth is requesting a new loan of 15,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This will be her 8th loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve her business. 

About ASKI:

ASKI is one of the most successful micro-finance institutions in the Philippines. It has 25 branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: The Fullness Of Time Group

texts.en:
David S. is the leader of a group of five borrowers called The Fullness of Time. He is 53 years old, married, and has eight children who range in age from 3 to 23 years old. He was able to graduate from high school but could not continue to college due to poverty.

For two years, David has been selling charcoal at the Thinker Village in Paynesville, Liberia. He sells good charcoal in a friendly manner, which keeps customers returning.

David plans to use his 6,000-LRD portion of this 30,000-LRD group loan to buy more charcoal. His goals are to grow his business and to have a good life.

In the photo that accompanies this profile, David is the person holding the sign.

About LEAP:
The Local Enterprise Assistance Program (LEAP) is Liberia's largest and oldest continuously operating microfinance institution with 13 branches across the country. Founded in 1994, the non-profit organization has survived periods of civil war and severe socioeconomic hardship. LEAP seeks to help rebuild post-conflict Liberia through its group and individual loans to micro- and small-scale entrepreneurs, and LEAP puts emphasis on lending to women.

loans.use: To buy more charcoal

loans.name: Ob

texts.en: Ob C., aged 39, is married and resides with her five children in Kampong Chnang Province, Cambodia. She is engaged in a business of selling various kinds of groceries in her village, earning a gross income of USD 15 per day to help cover the family's expenses. Her husband is a construction worker in the city, earning an income of USD 6 per day. Their standard of living has improved since Ob C. and her husband have had these businesses. She is requesting a loan of USD 500 to purchase more groceries to stock her store. This is her first loan from CREDIT, a Kiva partner.

loans.use: To buy more groceries to stock her store

loans.name: Celsa Arelis

texts.es:
La señora Celsa Arelis B., trabaja por cuenta propia se dedica a la venta de refrescos en la terminal de buses del bisne, es soltera habita en barrio Divino Niño tiene dos hijos en edad escolar. 

La señora Arelis B. solicita crédito con CEPRODEL desde hace seis años y siempre ha pagado en tiempo y forma, lo utiliza para la compra de productos envasados como gaseosas, jugos, aguas purificadas,  etc.
texts.en:
Celsa Arelis B. is self-employed; she sells soft-drinks at the El Bisne bus terminal. She is single and lives in the Divino Niño neighborhood with her two, school-age children. Mrs. Arelis B. has had CEPRODEL loans for the last 6 years and she has always repaid in a timely fashion. She will use this new funding to buy packaged items like: soft-drinks, juices, purified water, etc.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy stock inventory items.

loans.name: Nataliya

texts.en:
Nataliya is divorced with two grown children. She is an entrepreneur from Ivano-Frankivsk. Nataliya used to work as a deputy director at a knitting factory. However, it was closed down and she was forced to launch her own trade. Now Nataliya sells men’s suits, pants and shirts in the central marketplace of her hometown. She offers a nice selection of assorted inventory at affordable prices. Nataliya has been in this trade for 10 years. Her monthly profit amounts to 5,000 UAH. 

Nataliya is seeking a loan of 7,500 UAH to purchase 100 pairs of men’s pants for further retail sale. This business is the main source of income for Nataliya. She started with one vending location. Lending assistance helped her open her second location. She is hoping to continue growing her business in the future.

loans.use: To purchase 100 pairs of pants

loans.name: Miguel

texts.es:
El  Sr. Miguel S. P. es de la ciudad de Santani, del Barrio Monte Alto, tiene 43 años de edad, esta casado con la Sra. Teodolina Ovando de S. de 39 años de edad, Actualmente tienen 4 hijos todos Mayores de edad.
 Posee una Joyería con relojería en el centro de la ciudad, el atiende el negocio ofreciendo sus joyas a los clientes.
Las joyas que el comercializa los compra de la ciudad de Luque.
Es un familia muy trabajadora que procura bastante para vivir de la mejor manera posible.
Actualmente quiere renovar los modelas de joyas y relojes que ofrece pero no cuenta con el capital suficiente por lo que solicita el préstamo.
Agradece a la Fundación Paraguaya y Kiva ya que facilita el trabajo de mucha gente con escasos recurso y espera que siga ayudando.
texts.en:
Miguel S. P. is from the Monte Alto neighborhood in the city of Santani. He’s 43 years old, married to Teodolina Ovando de S., 39; they have four adult children. He has a jewelry shop downtown that he runs himself offering jewelry that he brings from the city of Luque for sale to his customers. This is a hard-working family that puts much effort into living in the best possible way. He wants to update his watch and jewelry stock items but lacks enough funds to do so; thus this loan request. He is grateful to Fundación Paraguaya and to Kiva because of the help they offered to many low-income people so that they can continue working; he hopes they will continue to help.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy jewelry and watches.

loans.name: Pierrette

texts.fr: A. Pierrette est mariée et mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont deux sont à sa charge. Pierrette vit à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis cinq ans. Pierrette vit seule avec ses enfants et assure leurs différentes charges. Pour y arriver, Pierrette vend divers produits vivriers (maïs, haricot, farine de manioc, igname, etc.), à son domicile. Pierrette achète ses produits à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin. Pierrette exerce cette activité depuis cinq ans et a obtenu une fois déjà de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Pierrette a bien remboursé ledit crédit. Pierrette sollicite à nouveau un prêt, en vue d’augmenter le stock de ses produits et d’accroître sa clientèle, pour se faire plus de profits.
texts.en:
Pierrette A. is married and the mother of four children, all attending (or having attended) school, of whom two are under her care. She has been living in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji commune, for the past five years. She lives alone with her children and is their sole support. To make ends meet, Pierrette sells a variety of produce (corn, beans, cassava flour, yams, etc.) from her home. She buys her products in Dantokpa, Benin’s international marketplace. Pierrette has been running this business for five years and has already been granted one loan from ALIDé, which she duly reimbursed. She is now requesting another loan, to increase her stock supply as well as her customer base, and make more profit.

Translated from French by René McConnell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy corn, beans, rice, and yams

loans.name: Dina

texts.es:
Dina es socia del Bancomunal Paloma, es conviviente, tiene 6 hijos el mayor de 20 años y el menor de 14. Dina tiene una chicharroneria en un local alquilado este negocio lo maneja con su esposo desde hace 10 años, antes se dedicaba a la venta de emoliente.
Gracias a los prestamos que ha recibido ha podido comprar su casa, su esposo también le ayuda, es chofer de ruta.
Dina tiene en FINCA 12 años aproximadamente, gracias a los prestamos que ha recibido ha podido mejorar su negocio, pues le ha apoyado en la inversión y gracias a las capacitaciones sabe como tratar a sus clientes.
Dina solicita un préstamo de 400 soles, dinero que será utilizado en la compra de 20 cajas de bebidas para su negocio.
Su sueño es sacar adelante a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Dina is a member of the Paloma (The Dove) communal bank; she has 6 children the oldest of whom is 20 years old and the youngest is 14. She rents a locale where she runs a chicharronería (fried pork) with her husband; she’s been in this business for 10 years but used to sell herbal teas before this. Thanks to the loans she has gotten she’s been able to buy her house. Her husband, who is a public transportation provider, helps her out. Dina has been collaborating with FINCA for about 12 years and the loans have made it possible for her to make improvements to her business because she’s been able to invest in it and thanks to the training sessions she has learned how better to treat her customers. Dina is asking for a 400 sol loan to buy 20 cases of beverages. Her dream is to successfully raise her children.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy 20 cases of beverages.

loans.name: Jihad

texts.en:
Jihad is a 41-year-old man from Lebanon. Jihad is married and the father of six children. Jihad is a farmer. His main interest is in raising different types of livestock, especially goats, sheep, and cows. Since 2000, he runs his own farm. He is proud of this. His customers include people from his region and its surroundings. He notes that when he first started his business, he had some difficulties in starting up, but he prevailed.

Today, for the first time, he has requested a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua. He plans to purchase a cow with this loan. For the future, he plans to keep on improving his work and is confident that his loan will allow him to grow his business.

loans.use: To purchase a cow

loans.name: Nov

texts.en: Nov Sovannaroth, 24, is married and resides with her husband and two children in Siem Reap Province, Cambodia, an area known for the most favorite tourist places in the country. Sovannaroth raises pigs, earning an income of $3 US per day. Her husband is a construction worker and earns an income of  $5 per day. Sovannaroth is requesting a loan of $400 to purchase more pigs to raise, and a motorbike for the family use. In the future, she would like to use any additional profit to repair her house.  This is her third loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: buy a motorbike and pigs

loans.name: Tièssiri 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les huit femmes du groupe Tièssiri 1 sont mariées majoritairement dans des grandes familles polygames, avec en moyenne 34 ans et 5 enfants. Elles vivent toutes dans le village de Siradjankoro dans la commune rurale de Pelengana dans la région de Ségou (4ème région administrative du Mali) et se sont connues à travers des liens de mariage, de voisinage et de parenté. 
Dans le but d'augmenter leurs superficies de culture, elles ont fait recours à Soro Yiriwaso et sont à leur 1ier  cycle de prêt de campagne. 
Les membres du groupe vont cultiver le mil, l’arachide et le fonio.
Madame Fatoumata  Traoré compte utiliser son prêt pour acheter 25kg de semences d’arachide,  un sac de complexe céréale et recruter la main d’œuvre pour les activités de labour et de récolte  pour son champ d’arachide. 
Elle se ravitaille en intrants agricole à la foire Cinzana Gare et en main d’œuvre avec l’association des jeunes et des femmes du village. 
Avec une superficie de 2,50 hectares, Madame Fatoumata   Traoré espère produire 18 sacs d’arachide et 8 sacs de mil. 
Toute la production du mil serait auto consommée tandis que celle d’arachide sera vendue pour satisfaire les besoins du foyer en condiments et soins de santé des enfants. 
Madame Fatoumata Traoré à l’image des autres femmes du groupe Tièssiri a pour objectif d’assurer l’auto suffisance alimentaire dans le village et faire de l’élevage des petits ruminants.
texts.en:
The eight women of the group Tièssiri 1 are predominantly married into large polygamous families, are on average 34 years old and have 5 children. They all live in the village of Siradjankoro in the rural community of Pelengana in the region of Ségou (4th administrative region of Mali) and know one another through marital, parental and neighborhood ties. With the goal of increasing their cultivable lands, they appealed to Soro Yiriwaso and are on their 1st farm loan. The members of the group are going to cultivate millet, peanuts and fonio (a type of millet produced in Mali). Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré expects to use her loan to buy 25 kg of peanut seeds, a bag of complex fertilizers, and to recruit the manual labor for the labor and harvesting for the peanut fields. She refreshes her supply of agricultural inputs at the fair in Cinzana Gare and gets her manual labor from an association of young people and women from the village. With 2.5 hectares of land, Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré hopes to produce 18 bags of peanuts and 8 bags of millet. She will consume all the millet she produces, while the peanuts she produces will be sold to satisfy the household needs in condiments and to care for the health of her children. Mrs. Fatoumata Traoré, like the other women of the Tièssiri group, has as her objective the dietary self-sufficiency of the village and to raise small ruminant animals.

Translated from French by Martha Schmitz, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy peanut seeds, complex fertilizer, and to use manual labor for the labor and harvesting

loans.name: Meong

texts.en: Meong K., 51, is married and resides with his wife and three children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-Angkorean temples. He is a teacher at a public school in the province and earns an income of $ 2.30 (USD) per day. His wife raises poultry at home, earning an income of $1.50 per day.  K. is requesting a loan of $600 to purchase cows to resell. In the future, he would like to use any additional profit to repair his house.  This is his first loan from CREDIT, a long-standing Kiva partner in Cambodia.

loans.use: to buy cows to resell

loans.name: Willa

texts.en:
Willa R. is from the village of Poblacion, Don Carlos, Bukidnon. She is 55 years old. Willa is married and has 5 adult children. To make a living, Willa owns & operates a business primarily selling snacks & other delicacies like steamed sweetcorn in the local community. Her husband is her business partner. Willa has been engaged in her business for over 6 years and earns approximately 8000 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2010, Willa joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. Willa is requesting a new loan of 5000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make the products she has for sale. This will be the 1st loan taken out by Willa from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more bags of slippers

loans.name: Maria Elena

texts.es: DOÑA ELENA C. S., TIENE 35 AÑOS,  VIVE CON SU ESPOSO, QUIEN SE DEDICA AL COMERCIO. TIENEN UNA HIJA Y ESTUDIA. DOÑA ELENA COMENZO CON SU TIENDECITA HACE 10 AÑOS CON EL OBJETIVO DE SOBRESALIR Y TENER UN NEGOCIO PROPIO Y FORMALIZARCE, SU MADRE LE DIO UN LOCAL DONDE ELLA EMPEZARIA A VENDER PRODUCTOS DE LA CANASTA BASICA, TODOS LOS DIAS ATIENDE DESDE LAS 6:00 AM Y HASTA LAS 10:00PM. SEÑALA QUE LA MEJOR FORMA DE OBTENER CLIENTES ES BRINDAR UN BUEN SERVICIO Y SIEMPRE BRINDAR UNA SONRISA Y ASI LOGRA EL RETORNO DE LOS MISMOS. SE SIENTE MUY CONTENTA POR PODER AYUDAR A SOLVENTAR LOS GASTOS DE SU FAMILIA, QUIEN INDICA SON LO MAS IMPORTENTE EN SU VIDA. DOÑA ELENA TIENE YA  AÑOS DE ESTAR TRABAJANDO CON FAPE Y PIENZA QUE ES TIEMPO DE CRECER AUN MAS Y ES POR ESO QUE SOLICITA UN CREDITO AUN MAYOR, QUE SERÀ INVERTIDO EN LA COMPRA DE PRODUCTOS DE LA CANASTA BASICA  LA SEÑORA ELENA HA DEMOSTRADO SER UNA PERSONA MUY RESPONSABLE Y COMO ELLA DICE ES LA FORMA DE DEMOSTRAR SU AGRADECIMIENTO  A FAPE.
texts.en:
Doña Elena C. S. is 35 years old and lives with her husband. She works as a merchant and has a daughter who is in school. Doña Elena started her small store ten years ago so that she could get ahead and have her own formal business. Her mother provided her with a place where she could begin selling basic food products. Every day she manages her business between the hours of 6am and 10pm. Elena says the best way to attract customers is to provide good service and always do it with a smile. In return, her customers do the same. She feels happy to be helping with the expenses of her family, since they are the most important thing in her life.

Doña Elena has been working with FAPE for several years and believes she can grow even more this time. For this reason, she is requesting a larger loan to invest in the purchase of more food products. Sra. Elena has demonstrated that she is a very responsible person and says she hopes to demonstrate her appreciation to FAPE.

loans.use: Purchase basic food products

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase a motorbike.

loans.name: Kat's Group

texts.en:
Mrs. Khat S. is 41 years old and is a villager who lives in Chong Preaek village in Kandal province. Mrs. Khat S. is tH. village bank president, having been selected by its nine members who all live in Chong Preaek village together. 

Mrs. Khat S. is a farmer who owns a piece of land that sH. uses to cultivate rice. To support this farming, Mrs. Khat S. decided to ask for a loan to purchase fertilizer and pesticide for her rice. SH. plans to buy motorbike repair supplies for her husband's business with any remainder of tH. loan. Her husband, Mr. Choy Ny, is 52 years old and work as a motorcycle repairman who is able to earn some income to support his family. This couple has two children who are too young to study or work.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer and pesticide to cultivate rice

loans.name: Amor

texts.en: Amor A. is from the village of Quiboro, Mambajao, Camiguin Province. She is 30 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. To make a living, Amor owns and operates a business venture in the retail sector running a sari-sari (variety) retail shop, buying and selling daily use products such as shampoo, soap, toothpaste, canned goods, instant noodles and junk foods in the local community. Amor has been engaged in her business for over 4 years and earns approximately 5,000 PHP a month from these activities. In 2010, Amor joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Amor is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Amor from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: José Manuel

texts.es:
José Manuel es un padre de familia de 39 años de edad que reside junto a su esposa y a sus hijos en el caserío Quemazón, una zona agrícola que está habitada principalmente por personas humildes y bastante trabajadoras, pertenece al distrito de Mórrope y se encuentra ubicada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a comercializar carbón vegetal entre sus vecinos. Este producto tiene  bastante uso entre los pobladores de la localidad, ya que la mayoría de familias se vale de él para cocinar sus alimentos porque no tienen acceso al gas propano. El mismo se encarga de talar los árboles de algarrobo, un árbol oriundo del norte del país y que abunda mucho por la zona, los cuales compra a los propietarios del terreno en donde se están ubicados para luego quemar la madera y convertirla en carbón.

José Manuel desea contar con un capital propio para poder comprar más árboles y ampliar su negocio, por ello ha decidido solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de  800 nuevos soles que le ayuden a lograr su meta.
texts.en:
José Manuel, 39, is a father living with his wife and children in Quemazón, a farming area inhabited for the most part by humble, quite hard working people.  It belongs to Mórrope district and is located in Lambayeque province over an hour away from the city of Chiclayo.

He sells plant-based charcoal among his neighbors.  This is a product that is quite widely used by area residents because most families use it to cook their meals because they don’t have access to propane gas.  He himself fells the carob trees, a tree native to the north of the country that is quite abundant in the area, that he buys from the property owners where the trees are located to later burn the wood and turn it into charcoal.

José Manuel wants to have capital of his own to be able to buy more trees and expand his business.  He, therefore, decided to ask Edpyme Alternativa for an 800 new sol loan that will help him reach his goal.

loans.use: To buy wood to make charcoal.

loans.name: Venancia

texts.en:
Venancia B. is from the village of Dimaluna, Ozamiz City. She is 56 years old, married, and has two school-aged and six adult-aged children. She owns and operates a business of selling dried fish at retail prices. She has been engaged in this business for two years and earns approximately $70 a month.

In July 2009, Venancia joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She had successfully repaid a previous loan of 14,995 PHP from PMPC. 

She is now requesting a new loan of 14,995 PHP which will be used to buy more dried fish to sell. This will be her 4th loan from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the living conditions of her family.

About PMPC:

Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To buy more dried fish to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Buying sugar, soap and cassava flour for resale

loans.name: Sao

texts.en: Sao C., 29, is married and resides with her husband and five children in Takeo Province, Cambodia, an area known for pre-angkorean temples. She sells clothes, earning an income of USD 15 per day. Her husband sells shoes and bags, earning an income of USD 5 per day to help cover the family expenses. Each month, the family has to spend USD 35 on food, USD 10 on the children’s education, and USD 30 on other necessary expenses. C. is requesting a loan of USD 900 to purchase a trailer to transport her clothes to sell. In the future, she would like to use any additional income to repair her house. This will be her second loan from CREDIT, a longstanding Kiva partner.

loans.use: Buy a trailer to transport her clothes to sell

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
Luis forma parte del banco comunal “Cascada de Oro” perteneciente a la ciudad de Osorno. Él empezó vendiendo cajones de fruta y ahora tiene un minimarket en su casa, desde hace 5 años, en donde atiende junto a su esposa, quien también forma parte de Fondo Esperanza. Tiene una hija de 21 años, quien este año comienza a estudiar enfermería en la universidad. Entre los tres se turnan para atender el negocio todos los días de la semana desde las 7 hrs. de la mañana hasta las 11 hrs. de la noche.
Con este préstamo ampliará un metro y medio su negocio hacia delante, y comprará una vitrina y pasteles, ya que incluirá pastelería a su negocio. 
Vive con su esposa, sus dos hijos: la mayor de 21 y el menor de 15 y su única nieta de 4 años.
Su sueño es pagar los estudios de sus hijos, para que ellos tengan mejores oportunidades laborales. 
Para Luis y su esposa, Fondo Esperanza ha sido un importante aporte para su negocio, ya que gracias a los préstamos que han obtenido, han ido creciendo de a poco, incluyendo las máquinas necesarias y una mayor variedad de mercadería. También le han servido mucho  los talleres de educación emprendedora y de desarrollo personal que se les entregan durante las reuniones de banco comunal de parte de su asesor de Fondo Esperanza.
Osorno es una ciudad que se ubica en la zona sur de Chile, región de Los Lagos. Es un importante centro agropecuario que se identifica como "La Patria de la Leche y Tierra de la Carne" de Chile. Dentro de su actividad agropecuaria se destaca el cultivo de trigo y avena, la crianza de ganado, para el procesamiento de carnes y lácteos además de la fabricación de equipos agrarios.
Destaca en Osorno el único estadio de fútbol techado de Chile, el Estadio Municipal "Rubén Marcos”.
texts.en:
Luis is a member of the “Cascada de Oro” ("Shower of Gold") community bank in the city of Osorno in Chile.  He began selling boxes of fruit.  For the last five years, he has had a minimarket in his home, where he and his wife, who is also a part of the Esperanza microfinance partner, both work.  He has a  daughter, who started studying nursing at the university this year.  The three of them take turns attending the business every day of the week from 7 am to 11 pm.

Luis will use this loan to expand his business by one and a half meters in front and to buy a shop window and pastries, since his business includes a bakery. 

He lives with his wife, his two children, who are 21 and 15, and his only grandchild, who is 4 years old.

His dream is to pay for his children's education, so that they can have better employment opportunities.

Esperanza has played an important role in Luis and his wife's business, as the loans they have obtained have helped them to grow slowly, allowing them to buy the necessary machinery and making it possible for them able to offer a greater selection of products.  They have also taken advantage of the business education and personal development workshops, which Esperanza holds during the meetings of the communal bank.
 
Osorno is a city in southern Chile, in the Lagos region.  It is an important livestock area, known in Chile as "The Country of Milk and the Land of Meat."  Farmers also grow wheat and oats as feed, for meat and milk processing, as well as for the use by agrarian groups.

Osorno has the only enclosed football stadium in Chile, the  "Rubén Marcos” municipal stadium.

loans.use: Expansion, buying a shop window and pastries

loans.name: Shirley

texts.en:
This is Shirley T., 42, resident of Caloocan City, Philippines. She is married to Redentor T., and she is a mother of four. Together with her husband and children they manage their household while operating a business. She is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Shirley operates a variety store where she also sells cooked food such as breakfast and lunch fare. In the Philippines, a variety store is a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a Php5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Arlene earns income by purchasing items at wholesale prices and selling them individually. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 400 in sales every day.

To help her continue the operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Shirley hopes to be able to expand soon. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory

loans.name: Kipema Ole

texts.en:
Kipema ole M. N. is 44 years old. He is married and supports six people. Kipema is a farmer and he does the farming on his own piece of land as he has been doing for the last fourteen years.

He learned about KADET LTD from credit officers in their local marketing. This will be his first loan which he is planning to spend to purchase farm inputs. He hopes to use the profit from the proceeds of this loan to expand his farming activity from small-scale to commercial farming.

Kipema's dream is to practise large-scale farming and attain financial independence. He is a hard-working man who is determined to achieve his set goals.

loans.use: to purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Felix

texts.es:
El Sr. Felix B., tiene  32 años de edad, está casado con la Sra. Leda González hace cuatro años, tienen un hijo juntos  de un año, vive en el Barrio Capitan Roa de la Ciudad Coronel Oviedo.
El Sr. Felix  tiene su local de Gomería en el centro de la ciudad, es gomero de profesión, aprendió el oficio de su difunto padre.
Comenta que le gusta su profesión, más aún porque es legado de su padre, a quien ayudó en la crianza de todos sus hermanos, siempre trabajó con su padre y después de su fallecimiento heredó el negocio, hace más de tres años.
Lo gerencia con todo orgullo, porque es una profesión en donde pone toda su energía todos los días.
Se acercó a la Fundación Paraguaya con el objetivo de recibir ayuda crediticia que le ayude a salir adelante. Y desde ya agradece a la institución por la oportunidad que se le brinda.
texts.en:
Felix B., is 32 years old, and has been married to Leda González for four years, they have a one year old son, and live in the Capitan Roa suburb of Coronel Oviedo city.
Felix has his tire shop in the city center, he repairs tires as a profession, he learnt this skill from his late father.
He says that he likes his profession, even more so as it is a legacy from his father, who he helped in raising all his siblings. He always worked with his father and after his death he inherited the business, more than three years ago.
He manages it with a lot of pride, because it is a profession that he can put all his energy into every day.
He approached the "Fundación Paraguaya" for the purpose of receiving financial support to help him get ahead. And he is grateful to the institution for the opportunity that it has offered him.

loans.use: To buy car tires

loans.name: 050420 - Trung Trieu - Hoang Phong Group

texts.en:
"Yen  L. T. (9) is a 45 year-old femaL. living in the town of Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Yen  is the group leader of a 6-member group loan offered by Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  WhiL. each member of the group receives an individual loan, they all are responsibL. for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.  The official name of this borrowing group is 050420 - Trung Trieu - Hoang Phong (050420 - Trung Trieu - Hoang Phong).


Yen  is married and has 2 school-age children.  To making a living, Yen  operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising livestock.  The main source of income for the business comes primarily from raising cattL. for saL..  Yen  has been engaged in this business for over 20 years and earns approximately 5000000 VND a month from these activities.


In 2005, Yen  joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities.  Yen  has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5000000 VND from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  This previous loan was used to invest in renovating the business.  She is now requesting a new loan of 7000000 VND which will be used to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future.  The loan will be the 9th loan taken out by yen from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Yen  plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family.


About the Other Borrowers in the Group:


1.  Nhan N. T. (11) is a 52 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 7000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


2.  Giang L. T. (12) is a 52 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 7000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


3.  Huong N. T. (31) is a 33 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 7000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


4.  Nga L. T. (10) is a 39 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 7000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


5.  Ninh L. T. (44) is a 48 year-old femaL. who is requesting a 7000000 VND loan to support her business in the agriculture sector raising livestock.


About Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

The mission of Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) is to provide sustainabL. financial services to disadvantaged women in rural areas in the Thanh Hoa province.


*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in Vietnamese whiL. providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.


Yen  L. T. (9) là 45 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy sống ở thành phố Hoang hoa - Thanh hoa.  Yen  là trưởng nhóm của nhóm vay gồm có 6 các thành viên.  Mặc dù mỗi thành viên trong nhóm nhận được từng khoản vay cá nhân, nhưng tất cả họ đều chịu trách nhiệm hoàn trả lại khoản vay của các thành viên trong nhóm của mình nếu một người nào đó trễ hạn hay không trả được nợ..  Tên chính thức của nhóm vay này là 050420 - Trung Trieu - Hoang Phong (050420 - Trung Trieu - Hoang Phong).


Trong khi không phải chỉ có các phương thức tạo nên thu nhập, mà nguồn thu nhập chính của công việc kinh doanh chủ yếu từ chăn nuôi gia súc để bán.  Yen  thực hiện công việc kinh doanh này trong hơn 20 năm.  Từ các hoạt động này, Yen  kiếm được khoảng 5,000,000 VND.  Vào 2005, Yen  đã tham gia Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women để có thể tiếp cận với các dịch vụ tài chính giúp cải T.ện  sinh hoạt và khả năng tham gia vào các hoạt động kinh doanh của cô ấy/ anh ấy.  Yen  đã hoàn trả hết khoản vay trước đây là 5,000,000 VND từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.  Khoản vay trước đây được sử dụng đầu tư đổi mới công việc kinh doanh.  Cô ấy hiện đang đề nghị một khoản vay mới là 7,000,000 VND.


Khoản vay sẽ là 9th khoản vay của người vay từ Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.


Về Những Người vay khác trong Nhóm:


1.  Nhan N. T. (11) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


2.  Giang L. T. (12) là 52 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


3.  Huong N. T. (31) là 33 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


4.  Nga L. T. (10) là 39 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


5.  Ninh L. T. (44) là 48 tuổi nữ.  Cô ấy đề nghị khoản vay là 7000000 VND.  Khoản vay này sẽ được sử dụng để hỗ trợ công việc kinh doanh trong lĩnh vực nông nghiệp.  Mục đích chính của việc kinh doanh là chăn nuôi gia súc.


Về Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women:

Nhiệm vụ của Quỹ Hỗ trợ Phụ Nữ Nghèo Thanh Hóa (FPW) là cung cấp các dịch vụ tài chính bền vững cho những người phụ nữ kém may mắn ở các vùng nông thôn tỉnh Thanh Hóa.


*Lưu ý: Để phát huy tối đa hiệu quả & giảm chi phí, khoản vay này đã được thông báo bằng biểu mẫu để có thể được Kiva tự động biên dịch. .  Do việc biên dịch thủ công các danh mục rất tốn kém, nên Kiva đã tạo biểu mẫu này cho phần Field Partner (Trường Đối Tác) cho phép họ tiếp tục thông báo các khoản vay bằng  Vietnamese trong khi cung cấp thông tin có chất lượng & chính xác cho người cho vay Kiva.  ."

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise & sell in the future

loans.name: Darwin Franco

texts.es:
Darwin tiene 30 años de edad que reside junto a su familia en el distrito de Jayanca. Una zona agrícola, donde se ubican empresas industriales, que se ubica a una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Darwin se dedica al rubro de construcción como maestro de obras (persona que se dedica  a la construcción de viviendas o edificios teniendo a su cargo a varias personas que realizan esta actividad), esta actividad la realiza desde hace 8 años por tal motivo conoce a la perfección este rubro, contando con clientela establecida. 

El desea ampliar su negocio, adquiriendo herramientas que le permitan realizar con más facilidad su trabajo, recibiendo mayores ingresos, lo que le permitirá realizar algunas mejoras en su vivienda de modo que su familia pueda vivir en mejores condiciones. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 1200 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Darwin, 30, lives with his family in Jayanca District, a farming zone where industrial firms are located.  It is located an hour away from the city of Chiclayo.

Darwin is a Master Builder (a person who builds houses or buildings who supervises several people who do this kind of work).  He’s been in this line of work for 8 years so knows it to perfection and has an established customer base.

He wants to expand the business acquiring tools that will make it possible for him to do the work more easily, earning better income which will permit him to do some home improvements so that his family can live under better conditions.  Because of this, he’s thought it wise to request his first, 1200 new sol, loan from Edpyme Alternativa.

loans.use: to acquire work tools.

loans.name: Sop Serigne Bara Group

texts.fr:
Sop Serigne Bara est un groupe de solidarité du Banc Villageois de Artillerie Baax Yaay qui est créé le 27 août 2009; il est composé de 15 femmes qui sont issues du même quartier, elles ont comme lien commun le petit commerce et s'entendent bien.

La responsable Madame Nogaye S. est âgée de 49 ans elle a neuf enfants en charge dont quatre orphelins de père et mère. Elle es à l'extrême droite sur la photo habillée de rose blanc avec un châle blanc. Elle mène une activité de petit commerce de fruits selon les saisons et la période: des mangues, oranges, mandarines, pastèques et melons. Elle a une expérience de 12 ans dans ce domaine.

Son prêt lui permettra de renforcer son petit commerce pour avoir beaucoup de revenus.

Elle participe aux dépenses quotidiennes, assure l'habillement des enfants; le reste est à la charge de son mari.
texts.en: The Sop Serigne Bara "Banc Villageois" is a solidarity group in Artillerie Baax Yaay, born on August 27, 2009. The 15 members are women who all come from the same district. Also, they all have small business and get along with each other. Madam Nogaye S., 49 year-old, is the leader of the group. She is in charge of 9 children and 4 of them are orphans. She is on the far right in the picture wearing white and pink cloth. She sells different fruits depending on the season: mangoes, oranges, tangerines, watermelons and melons. She has a 12 years experience in the field and the loan will allow her to strengthen her small business of fruits and to have more income. She participates to the daily expenditures and takes care of the children's clothing. Her husband is in charge of the rest.

loans.use: To buy and resell fruits depending on the season

loans.name: Erlinda

texts.en:
Erlinda B. is 56 years old and married with seven adult-aged children. Erlinda earns about PHP 4,000 when she sells one of her raised hogs. 

Erlinda has been raising hogs for 25 years. Erlinda is asking for a loan of 6,000 PHP to purchase additional breeding hogs and feed.

In the future, Erlinda hopes to strengthen the kind of business she manages to make it more profitable in order to improve their living conditions.

loans.use: to purchase additional hogs and feed

location.town: Mabasa, Dupax del Norte, Nueva Vizcaya

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 43 yrs old.  She is married to Joseph who also contributes to the family income. She is a farmer and has been operating her farm for a period of about nine years, earning an income of about KES 10,000 per month.

Beatrice is taking out her second loan after successfully repaying the previous one.  She wants to use this loan to buy more dairy cows and to cultivate her farm. Her hope is to own a large-scale farm and improve the living standard for her family.

loans.use: to buy dairy cows and cultivate her farm

loans.name: Dionicia

texts.es:
La señora Dionicia, vive en Coapilla Estado de Chiapas México, vive en unión libre con el señor  Daniel, en la cual procreo dos hijos: Daniela Judith de seis años y Kevin Gabriel de dos años de edad.

   Solicito el préstamo para invertirlo en la compra de ingredientes para la elaboración de panes, en donde lleva  un año practicándolo y dice que ve que le está yendo bien ya que le está dejando buenos ingresos y ganancias dentro de su actividad.

   Se inspiro en ello ya que lo aprendió con su suegra  y decidió practicarlo para tener sus propios ingresos y así poyar a su esposo con un poco de dinero, para que juntos le den lo mejor a sus dos hijos que están creciendo.

   Lo que ella desea  es que la apoyando  con el préstamo y así seguir trabajando para mejorar su calidad de vida y logre tener sus propios ahorros.
texts.en:
Dionisia lives in Coapilla, Chiapas, Mexico. She lives with her husband, Daniel, with whom she has two children: Daniela Judith, 6, and Kevin Gabriel, 2. 

She is requesting the loan to purchase ingredients to bake breads, which she has been doing for a year and says that it's going well since she's earning a good income. 

She motivated herself to start the job, which she learned from her mother-in-law, and decided to start doing it to earn her own income and support her husband with a little money so together they can give the best to their growing children. 

Dionisia hopes to get some support from the loan so she can keep working to improve her quality of life and have her own savings.

loans.use: to purchase ingredients (eggs, oil, flour, cheese, etc.) to bake her breads.

loans.name: Amor Y Amistad 3 & 4 Group

texts.en:
Martire is the coordinator of his group Amor y Amistad 3 & 4 (Love and Peace). He makes his home here in a simple structure with his long-term partner and their two children.

Martire is excited to be taking his thirteenth loan with Esperanza, after having successfully repaid his previous loan and having developed his business by expanding his client base and by buying more products. He has had his business for around eight years, starting with the first loan he received from Esperanza, after some neighbors invited him to join the group. He plans to use this loan to invest in his business by purchasing pounds of fish and chicken to sell, as well as coconuts in order to sell their water. He will continue using his business profits to provide a better life for his family by building their house and by providing warm food, clothing, and for other needs.

His group is located in Samana, a lush rugged peninsula with a burgeoning tourism industry, where most of the group members sell their products in their communities and surrounding areas. Martire thanks you for your support in helping them achieve their dreams of being successful in the future.

loans.use: to buy coconut, fish, and chicken.

loans.name: Rita Marie

texts.en:
Rita Marie is 22 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 1 child. 
Rita Marie has a food shop that sells viands like chicken & pork adobo (pork seasoned with soy, garlic, vinegar and spices). She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy raw ingredients needed for cooking dishes.
Rita Marie has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Rita Marie hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients needed for cooking dishes

loans.name: Valentine

texts.en:
Valentine is a 29 year old Rwandan entrepreneur with 4 children between the ages of 3 and 9 years old.  All are in school. 

For the past 9 years, she and her and husband have run a business selling second hand shoes. 

Valentine will use the money from this loan to purchase more shoes so that she can increase her profits. She hopes to build up enough capital so that she can expand her business by selling a greater variety of goods in addition to  second hand shoes.

loans.use: to purchase more shoes for sale

loans.name: Mirian Yolanda

texts.es:
Mirian Yolanda tiene 25 años de edad, es casada, vive con su esposo e hijo de 1 año, en el Cantón Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C 	ALLI KAUSAY, se encuentra ubicada en la comunidad Tolapungo, sector Veintimilla, perteneciente al cantón Guaranda, los miembros de esta ventanilla se dedican a la agricultura, crianza de animales, comercio de ganado, legumbres y otros.

Mirian se dedica al comercio de legumbres, agricultura, crianza de animales, su esposo de dedica a la construcción. Compra y vende sus productos en el mercado mayorista de Guaranda.
 
Solicita el crédito para pagar el transporte de legumbres, semillas para los cultivos y alimentacion para los animales de crianza . El  crédito le servirá de apoyo para suplir sus necesidades económicas y mejorar su calidad de vida. Enfrenta desafíos como la inestabilidad del precio de los animales. Su sueño es comprarse un terreno y construirse una casa en el centro de la ciudad.

Le gusta dedicarse a labores del hogar, y de vez en cuando visitar a su familia.
texts.en:
Mirian Yolanda, 25, is married and lives with her husband and one-year-old son in Guaranda Canton, Bolívar Province.

The members of the Alli Kausay communal bank are located in the community of Tolapungo, Veintimilla Sector, belonging to Guaranda Canton.  They are farmers, raise livestock, sell livestock, sell vegetables and others.

Mirian sells vegetables, farms, and raises animals.  Her husband works in construction.  Her purchases and her sales take place in the Guaranda wholesale market.

She is asking for the loan to pay for the transport of her vegetables, seeds for her fields, and feed for her livestock.  The loan will help her meet her economic needs and improve her quality of life.  She faces challenges like animal price instability.  Her dream is to buy a piece of property and build a house in the center of town.  She enjoys doing household chores and once in a while visiting her family.

loans.use: to pay for the transport of her vegetables, seeds for her fields, and feed for her livestock

loans.name: Be Glad Trust Bank Group

texts.en:
Rita is currently the group leader of the Be Glad Trust Bank Group made up of 9 members. She is a 26-year-old seamstress who is clearly active and hardworking. Rita sews for women and children according to the styles of her customers. She plans to use the requested loan to purchase sewing accessories to improve her products. Rita possesses 6 years of hands-on experience in sewing. 

Rita is married to a commercial driver and together they have one child who is 3 years old. She lives with her family in Takoradi, a coastal business hub of Ghana. Above all, she hopes to be financially able to support a building project to accommodate her family. As the leader of the group, Rita will ensure that all members attend meetings and submit their repayments.

loans.use: To purchase sewing accessories

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase bales of used clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ramona Castilla

texts.es:
Ramona Castilla tiene 46 años de edad, es soltera no tiene  hijos vive sola,  en el Canton Chillanes Provincia de Bolivar.

La V.R.C se llama EL PLACER perteneciente al Canton Chillanes parroquia San Jose del Tambo esta ubicada a 60 minutos de la oficina, en esta ventanilla hay 24 socios que se dedican a la agricultura a la siembra de Platano, arroz, yuca, cacao, soya y naranja ademas crian animales de corral.

Ramona se dedica a la siembra de arroz, maiz, naranja, soya y platano. Las compras las realiza en San Jose del Tambo y las Vende en el mercado de Chillanes los domingos en la feria.

El credito lo solicita para comprar de insumos agricolas y fertilizantes . El credito le ayudara como apoyo para mejorar la cosecha . Enfreta desafios como la edad y la salud. Su sueño es tener buena salud para trabajar.

En los tiempos libres le gusta salir a caminar por los teerenos y acompañar a los padres que estan enefermos.
texts.en:
Ramona Castilla is 46 years old. She is single and has no children. She lives alone in the Chillanes canton in the province of Bolivar.

The V.R.C. is called EL PLACER and belongs to the Chillanes canton, in the parish of San Jose del Tambo, which is located 60 minutes from the office. There are 24 members in this group who work in agriculture growing bananas, rice, cassava, cocoa, soya and oranges as well as breeding livestock.

Ramona works growing rice, corn, oranges, soya and banana. She makes her purchases in San Jose del Tambo and she sells them in the Chillanes market at the Sunday fair. 

She is asking for a loan to buy farming consumables and fertilizers. The loan will help support her in improving the harvest. She faces challenges such as old age and ill health. Her dream is to have good health in order to work.

In her free time she likes to walk the land in the company of her parents who are in ill health.

loans.use: to buy farming consumables and fertilizers.

loans.name: Compromiso Y Lealtad Group

texts.es:
Éste Banco comunal se llama “Compromiso y Lealtad” lo conforman 20 emprendedores quienes se dedican a diferentes rubros entre los cuales se encuentran venta de ropa, zapatos, artículos de aseo, gL. con helio, pollos asados, juguetes inflables para niños, ropa usada, herramientas, servicios de instalación de vidrios, repostería, artesanía en tejido, entre otros. Todos ellos pertenecientes a la comuna de Conchalí. 
Jessica integrante del Banco comunal, quien en la foto se encuentra en la segunda fila, ubicada en el segundo lugar de izquierda a derecha, vistiendo un sweater color negro y sosteniendo una carpeta de Fondo Esperanza en sus manos. Se dedica a la compra, reparación y venta de zapatos desde hace 11 años. Su trabajo consiste en comprar zapatos viejos o en desuso principalmente en ferias libres y luego restaurarlos y dejarlos como nuevos, para posteriormente venderlos. Oficio que le enseñó su padre. Ella vende en un persa, en un puesto con patente que le cedió su padre. 
Comenta que desde sus inicios le ha ido muy bien con el negocio, conserva clientela antigua por lo tanto también es fija. Jessica trabaja los días viernes y fines de semana. 
Su mercadería la compra en un sector llamado “Victoria”, ubicado en la ciudad de Santiago, ahí venden cueros, hilos, entre otros.
Con el crédito comprará zapatos. 
Sus metas en su negocio son comprar una camioneta para trasladar su mercadería. 
Jessica vive junto a su marido y sus dos hijas de 15 y 7 años de edad, sus sueños son costear los estudios superiores de sus hijas para que algún día, sean profesionales. 
Ella está muy contenta y agradecida de los servicios brindados por Fondo Esperanza, ya que le permitirá invertir en su negocio. Respecto al grupo dice tener muy buenas relaciones interpersonales con las demás emprendedoras. Además tiene muy buenas expectativas de las capacitaciones. Respecto a la socia que aparece en el recuadro superior izquierdo, debió ausentarse el día de la fotografia por motivos personales. 
Conchalí es una comuna de la región metropolitana (donde está Santiago, capital de Chile)  ubicada hacia el norte de la misma. Posee un barrio industrial delimitado, y múltiples actividades económicas y comerciales de pequeño tamaño, incluyendo ferias libres, talleres artesanales, garajes, terminales de buses, entre otros. El sector microempresarial es muy relevante en su actividad comercial.
texts.en:
This community bank is called “Compromiso y Lealtad” ('Commitment and Loyalty").  It is made up of 20 entrepreneurs who work in different fields, including selling clothes, shoes, cleaning items, helium balloons, roast chicken, inflatable toys for children, used clothes, tools; and services installing windows, confectionery, woven handicrafts, and other things.  They all live in the community of Conchalí.
 
Jessica is a member of the communal bank, who is in the second row of the photo, second from the left.  She is wearing a black sweater and holding a Fondo Esperanza folder.  She has been working buying, repairing and selling shoes for the last eleven years.  Her work consists of buying old or no longer used shoes, mainly at the markets, which she then repairs and makes like new, so she can sell them later on.  She learned this trade from her father.  She sells at a stall in a bazaar with a permit, which her father transferred to her.

She comments that her business has been going well for her since the start; she holds on to her old customers as they are loyal.  Jessica works Fridays and weekends.

She buys her merchandise in the Victoria neighborhood of Santiago city, where they sell leather and thread among other things.  She will buy shoes with the loan.

Her goals for her business are to buy a van for transporting her merchandise.
 
Jessica lives with her husband and two daughters, aged 15 and 7.  Her dreams are to pay for high-school education for her daughters so that they can one day become professionals.

She is very happy about the services provided by Fondo Esperanza and grateful for them, as they allow her to invest in her business.  In terms of the group, she has very good interpersonal relationships with the other entrepreneurs.  She also has very high expectations of the trainings. The member who appears in the upper left hand corner had to be absent the day the photo was taken for personal reasons. 

Conchalí is a community in the metropolitan region of Santigao, the capital of Chile, and is located in the northern part of that region.  It has a demarcated industrial neighborhood, and many small-sized economic and commercial activities including open markets, craft workshops, parking garages, bus terminals, among other things.  The micro-enterprise sector is very relevant with its commercial activity.

loans.use: to buy shoes.

loans.name: Olive

texts.en: Olive is 26 years old and has 4 children between the ages of 2 and 9. All of them attend school.  She is married to a businessman.  She sells vegetables at her own store which she has been running for 5 years. Olive wants a loan to buy more vegetables to sell. She will use the profits to create savings for her future and pay school fees for her children. She would like to see her business grow and prosper.

loans.use: To buy more vegetables for sale

loans.name: Nemesia

texts.en: Nemesia is 53 years old and lives in Dulapo, Oroquieta City. She is married with 4 children. Nemesia has an orchid vending business and earns approximately PHP 5,000 each month doing this type of work. She has a requested a loan of PHP 3,000 to purchase fertilizers for flowers for her business.  Nemesia has been a member of PMPC for 3 years.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers for flowers for her business.

loans.name: Linda

texts.en: Linda is a 29-year-old married woman with three children. All of them are in school. She sells charcoal in Kator, South Sudan. Mary requested this loan from BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal for sale. She hopes to pay the school fees for her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Marta

texts.es:
Marta es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Barbara” del distrito, provincia D. Yunguyo, departamento D. Puno, tiene  47  años D. edad, está casada y tiene tres hijos, dos independientes. Marta cuenta con estudios D. educación primaria.

Se dedica a la venta D. abarrotes, su primer préstamo fue por la suma D. S/. 300.00 nuevo soles, préstamo que invirtió en su negocio.

Solicitará un nuevo préstamo por la suma D. S/. 3000.00 nuevo soles, dinero que invertirá en la compra D. 5 sacos D. arroz, azúcar, harina, fideos, huevo y aceite.  Ella trabaja junto con su esposo.
Nos cuenta que la mercadería la venD. en la localidad D. Juliaca.

Su sueño es continuar con el negocio y mejorar sus ingresos.

Lo que más le gusta D. su Banco Comunal  es la puntualidad y las capacitaciones.
texts.en:
Marta is a member of the communal bank "Santa Barbara," in the district and province of Yunguyo, in the department of Puno.  She is 47 years old, married, and has 3 children, 2 of whom are independent.  Marta has an elementary school education.

Marta has a business selling groceries.  Her first loan was for the sum of 300 Peruvian soles, which she invested in her business.

She is requesting a new loan in the amount of 3,000 Peruvian soles to invest in the purchase of 5 sacks of rice, sugar, flour, noodles, eggs and cooking oil.  Her husband works with her in the business.

She tells us that she sells her merchandise in the town of Juliaca.

Her dream is to continue with her business and increase her income.

What she likes most about her communal bank is that the members are punctual with their payments, and she also likes the training.

loans.use: to purchase of 5 sacks of rice, sugar, flour, noodles, eggs and cooking oil.

loans.name: Peter

texts.en:
Peter is a farmer who lives in Kitale, Western Kenya.  He is 49 years old, married, and has five children. He has worked in farming for 20 years. His farm produces maize and beans, which he sells locally.

Peter has requested a loan of 80,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase poultry at 50,000 KES for a new poultry farming venture and to construct a dairy unit. He hopes to expand his farming business with the loan and to generate income to educate his children.

He says that some of the challenges in farming are the high cost of feed and animal diseases.

loans.use: to purchase poultry and construct a dairy unit.

loans.name: Jaribu Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Jaribu Group in Western Kenya! Jacklyn is the facilitator of the Jaribu group. This  group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jacklyn  takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jacklyn had a good maize yield harvesting 23 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jacklyn was only able to harvest 12 1/2 bags of maize on 1 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jacklyn  and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Jacklyn will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Jaribu group will each plant  between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Monicah

texts.en:
Monicah 64, is a mother of one child who graduated from school. She owns a house that neither has electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past two years, she has operated a retail shop business, selling to her neighbours and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her place of operation. Monicah dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale to meet her customers' demands. 

With the Kshs 20,000 she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and tea leaves.

loans.name: Juan

texts.es:
El Sr. Juan tiene 65 años, está casado con la señora Emerenciana, juntos tienen 2 hijos. Juan es macatero (vendedor ambulante), desde muy joven se dedica a este trabajo por lo que tiene mucha experiencia en el trabajo.
Realiza sus ventas por Gran Asunción, Villa Elisa, San Lorenzo, Capiata, desde muy joven macateaba con su papá, de quien aprendió a dedicarse a la venta. Ahora cuenta que gracias a este trabajo le dio educación a sus hijos, y que seguirá trabajando en esto por un tiempo más.
Solicita el crédito para compra de sábanas, colchas, sobrecamas, etc. los cuales son los principales productos que vende. Agradece a la fundación y a kiva por la oportunidad que esta le da.
texts.en:
Juan is 65 years old and married to Emerenciana; they have two children.  Juan is a “macatero” (itinerant vendor); he’s been in this line of work since he was young so he has a lot of experience in it.

He carries out his sales in Gran Asunción, Villa Elisa, San Lorenzo and Capiata.  He’s been street selling since he was very young and worked with his father from whom he learned how to dedicate himself to sales.  He comments that now thanks to this work he was able to provide education for his children and that he will continue working at this for more time.

He is asking for the loan to buy sheets, bedspreads, comforters, etc. which are the main products he sells.  He thanks the Fundación and Kiva for the opportunity they are giving him.

loans.use: to buy sheets, bedspreads and comforters.

loans.name: Adwowa

texts.en: Adwowa sells saucepans at Mpredwow. She is a single parent and has 3 children. She has been selling saucepans for some time now. She uses her income in clothing and feeding their children. Her loan will be used to buy more saucepans for sale. She hopes to use the new profits to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more saucepans for sale

loans.name: Rauben

texts.en:
Rauben is 40 years old and lives in the town of Rukoki in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. He is married and has 4 children - 3 of them are currently in school. For the past 3 years, Rauben has been working hard to manage his small business selling chicken. 

To help expand his business, Rauben has requested a loan of 2,000,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more chickens and feed for resale and will help Rauben to generate greater profits and pay his children's school fees. Rauben hopes that in the future he will be able to build a house in his second plot of land. 

Rauben is a member of BRAC's Small Enterprise Program (SEP).  The program primarily serves small entrepreneurs like Rauben who do not have enough collateral for commercial loans, but have businesses that have grown too large for microloans.

loans.use: to purchase more chickens and feed for resale.

loans.name: Abelino De Jesus

texts.es: Don Abelino habitante de com Bocana de Buena Vista, trabaja en su unidad de produccion en la que realiza ectividades agricolas y pecuarias, las cuales son de suma importancia y su principal fuente de ingreso para la sostenibilidad de su familia, realiza cultivo de maiz, frijoles y tuberculos los cuales le generan sus ingreso a la vez asegurar la dieta alimenticia, tambien cuenta con su pequeño inventario ganadero el cual le sirve para el fortalecimiento y mejorar su calidad de vida, nesecita este financiamiento para realizar establecimiento de 1.5 mzs del cultivo de yuca, actividad que le permitira incrementar su produccion de tuberculos, de manera que pueda elevar la rentabilidad para el bien comun de su familia.
texts.en:
Abelino lives in Bocana de Buena Vista.  He works in his fields doing agricultural and animal husbandry chores which are of utmost importance and his main source of income for family support; he grows corn, beans and tubers that both generate income and insure his family’s nourishment.  He also has a small herd of livestock that strengthens and improves his quality of life.  

He needs this financing to plant 1.5 manzanas [Central American unit of land measurement] of cassava root, an activity that will allow him to increase tuber production thus increasing profitability for his family’s welfare.

loans.use: to plant 1.5 acres of yuca

loans.name: Maxime

texts.en:
See Maxime at work: http://youtu.be/iYslpYCtVNo

Maxime is a solar lamp distributor in Mali. He is 46 years old, married and has three children. His background is agricultural engineering.

Maxime distributes solar lamps in five regions in Mali, including Kayes, Koulikoro, Sikasso, Segou and Mopti. He sells the majority of his solar lamps to poor rural populations such as miners, rice and grain farmers, women who produce cashews, shea butter and pepper, and students. Maxime partners with local cooperatives, teachers, and a network of nuns who live in rural communities to help organize events and raise awareness about the benefits of solar lamps. He also sells through two community associations: Eau Vive Mali and GASE Yeelen, where he serves as president.

Maxime’s customers currently rely on kerosene lamps and flashlights for light. Those that have mobile phones have to walk long distances and pay to charge their phone. They spend about $110 per year on kerosene and mobile phone charging. 

However, a solar lamp that provides 8 hours of high quality light a night and can charge a mobile phone costs just $25 and has a lifetime of about five years. There are no recurring costs as sunlight powers the lamp for free! 

Paying $25 up front for a solar lamp is difficult for Maxime’s customers, though. It is challenging to save that amount of money or to obtain a small, affordable loan.  Most of Maxime's customers earn about $2 a day, which barely covers basic needs like food. Banks only lend to people with a bank account and formal employment contracts, and microfinance institutions only make loans for business activities.

A Kiva loan will allow Maxime to purchase 2,000 solar lamps from NOTS Lampe Solaire on credit and then offer credit to his customers. Ultimately, this loan will enable Maxime to improve the livelihoods of about 10,000 people and reduce the negative impact of kerosene on the environment. Families save money on light and mobile phone charging, feel safer at night, are healthier (no toxic smoke from kerosene) and can increase their income because they are able to work at night. Children are also able to study longer. A win-win-win for everyone.

loans.use: to pay for solar lamps that he will sell on credit in rural communities.

loans.name: Ma. Consolacion

texts.en:
Ma. Consolacion is 44 years old, married with four children. All of her children are attend in school.

Ma. Consolacion works hard to provide for her family. She runs a general store in the Philippines and requested a PHP 30,000 loan through NWTF in order to buy more stocks of groceries to sell.

Ma. Consolacion has borrowed and paid 3 loans from NWTF before this loan. She has been running the general store for 15 years and also earns an income from farming sugarcane.

Ma. Consolacion aspires to save enough money to expand her business.

loans.use: to buy more stocks of groceries to sell.

loans.name: Ma Brigida

texts.en:
My name is Ma Brigida S. and I have been making and selling tortillas at my business for the last 3 years. My clients are very good and I sell to neighbors in my community as well as handle orders for clients that have other businesses such as supermarket merchants. My business allows me to support my family and provide them with education. My goal is to increase my inventory in order to have a better product to sell and will then be able to renovate my business (which is also where I live).

Translated from Spanish by Chloe Tuot, a Kiva Volunteer.

Mi nombre es Ma Brigida S. me dedico a la elaboración y venta de tortillas, tengo mi negocio hace unos 3 años, mis clientes son muy buenos y mis ventas las realizo con vecinos de mi localidad y clientes por encargos que tengo en diferentes negocios como ser mercaditos y pulperías, mi negocio me da utilidades que me ayudan a mantener a mi familia y darles su respectiva educación, mi meta es incrementar mi inventario para tener una mayor produccion y venta y asi poder remodelar mi negocio (casa de habitacion)

loans.use: Buy corn flour, water, salt, lime, phosphorous, firewood, charcoal

loans.name: Pauline Na Gana

texts.en:
Pauline is a widow with six children. She needed something to distract her from her memories of the death of her husband and son. She joined GHAPE in 2005 and benefitted from the social support provided by the group and center members. With her prior two loans, she succeeded in providing her community with cassava and acquired new skills to deal with her grief. She is hoping to provide for her children, grandchildren and herself in times of sickness.

Given a loan of $500, she plans to buy piglets, feed, medication, and rent a piece of land for cassava cultivation. She plans to pay monthly installments with the money she earns from selling manure and from her previous harvest. She plans to repay the loan in 18 months. The first installment will be four months from the date of disbursement of the loan.

loans.use: cultivation and trading

loans.name: Safura

texts.en: Safura G.  is married and lives in Beylagan.  She runs a small booth in the Beylagan city bazaar from which she sells women's clothes. Safura took out 4 loans from Normicro Beylagan Branch totaling $2500 in 2003-2006. Now she needs $900 to diversify her inventory. She thanks Normicro for its help.

loans.use: To diversify inventory

loans.name: Flora

texts.en:
From more than a block away, the smell of fresh-baked bread wafts down the streets of Ayacucho, Peru. In the middle of a residential block, behind large metal doors is the bakery that is the reason for the fragrant aroma. Haydee Flora R. answers the door, and gladly speaks about her successful business, which she has run for more than 18 years. She inherited the operation from her parents when they became too old to manage the operation, and Flora has since expanded and improved the bakery.

She has the help of three hardworking employees, and runs a very tight schedule. At 1 o’clock in the morning, the first worker arrives and starts the wood-burning fire that heats the stone oven used to cook the bread. Once the oven is hot enough, he begins the 2 hour process of baking the bread sold in the mornings for breakfast. Next, the workers (who clock 10 hour shifts) bake the other varieties sold throughout the day. The room containing the bread racks and oven is well over 90 degrees, and is saturated with the aroma of fresh baked bread.

Haydee Flora explains she produces over 20 types of bread, such as sweet breads made with sugar as well as French bread, dinner rolls, and many others. Once the bread has cooled, it is packaged in bags and distributed to small shops all over the city. She allows her employees to eat as much bread as they like, and says she herself has never grown bored of the bread she and her family eat daily. She lives in a home adjacent to the bakery with her husband and three children. She hopes to receive $1,000, which she would use to purchase the massive sacks of flour and sugar needed everyday, as well as repair the tricycles used for bread distribution.

loans.use: Purchase the massive sacks of flour and sugar needed everyday, as well as repair the tricycles used for bread distribution

loans.name: Sok

texts.en:
Mrs. Sok S. is 30 years old and lives with her 32-year-old husband and two children in the Kampong Cham district of Cambodia. Their children are both too young to attend school.

Sok S. and her husband own a grocery store, from which they earn $30 a day. Sok S. now wants to expand their store by buying extra products to sell in order to meet the increased demands of customers.

loans.use: Purchase more products to sell in grocery store

loans.name: Nuru

texts.en: Nuru is a 38-year-old mother of three and a resident of the Lumo area in Dar Es Salaam city. She has been in business for the past six years and currently runs a shop selling food items. She mainly deals in maize, flour, wheat, rice, beans and other cereal products that make up common meals for Dar Es Salaam city residents. She is in need of USD 225 to help her expand her business.

loans.use: EXPAND BUSINESS

loans.name: Hussein

texts.en: Hussein is a single 23 year old man who lives with his family in the Bekaa region of Lebanon. He owns a grocery shop and needs to buy merchandise to sustain and develop his business. Hussein is an independent and ambitious young man. He is determined to stand on his own feet and to help provide for his family.

loans.use: To buy merchandise for his grocery store

loans.name: Yat

texts.en:
Mrs. C. Yat (age 29) and her husband, Mr. Pin Sivan have been married since 2002.They have no children. Yat and her family are living on an island on the Mekong River about fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh. She is in the business of weaving silk.  She learned to weave silk from her mother and started her silk production in 1993. Her husband is also a silk weaver. It’s a skill he learned from his wife and he started his weaving in 2002.

Yat is requesting her third loan for the amount $400. She will use this money to purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.use: To purchase silk materials, sewing thread, fees for selecting and preparing silk on the loom.

loans.name: Mok

texts.en: Mrs. Mok B., 35, is a wholesaler, buying a variety of vegetables from Kampong Cham province to resell in Phnom Penh market, making on average about $13 a day of profit. Her husband, Mr. Em Phhal, 38, is banana seller. He purchases a large quantity of bananas from his community and resells them in the market, normally making $12 of profit. This couple has four children, two of whom are cleaners in Phnom Penh with a salary of $120 each a month.
